column12: INTERVERTEBRAL SPINAL IMPLANTS, ASSOCIATED INSTRUMENTS, AND METHODS THEREFOR
column13: To provide intervertebral spinal implants, associated instruments and methods therefor that may promote and enhance bone growth and bone fixation.SOLUTION: An intervertebral implant 100 may include an expandable implant including a superior endplate 110 and an inferior endplate. Each of the endplates may include a first portion 111 having a solid structure, and a second portion 113 having a porosity. The first portion comprises a plurality of transverse struts having voids located between the struts, and the second portion comprises a lattice structure 140 formed in each void. A bone funnel assembly may be used to inject a graft material into the implant.SELECTED DRAWING: Figure 1
column15: JOEL CRYDER;;DAVID FEIGENBAUM;;HILLARY KOPP;;MARK WEIMAN;;MARK MICCIO

Each of the endplates may include a first portion having a solid structure and a second portion having a porosity. column12: EXPANDABLE FUSIONS DEVICES, INSTRUMENTS, AND METHODS THEREOF
column13: Expandable fusion devices, systems, instruments, and methods thereof. The expandable fusion device is capable of being installed inside an intervertebral disc space to maintain normal disc spacing and restore spinal stability, thereby facilitating an intervertebral fusion. The fusion device may include a body, a first endplate, and a second endplate. A drive screw may be rotated to move the first and second endplates outwardly and into an expanded configuration. Instruments may be provided to ensure the implant is inserted safely and as intended.

column12: EXPANDABLE FUSION DEVICES, INSTRUMENTS, AND METHODS THEREOF
column13: To provide expandable fusion devices capable of being installed inside an intervertebral disc space to maintain disc spacing and restore spinal stability, thereby facilitating an intervertebral fusion, and capable of being expanded.SOLUTION: The invention provides expandable fusion devices, systems, instruments, and methods thereof. The expandable fusion devices are capable of being installed inside an intervertebral disc space to maintain normal disc spacing and restore spinal stability, thereby facilitating an intervertebral fusion. The fusion devices may include a body, a first endplate, and a second endplate. A drive screw may be rotated to move the first and second endplates outwardly into an expanded configuration. It is ensured that the implant is inserted safely and as intended.SELECTED DRAWING: Figure 18
